remixed_from.author: Pointedstick
remixed_from.title: RepRap X-carriage for self-aligning bronze bushings

title: Dave's Parametric X-Carriage for Self-Aligning Bushings

description.text: This is an OpenSCAD file to allow the selection of multiple options in creating an X-carriage for RepRap style 3D printers.

This was specifically created for MendelMax 3D printers. The recommendation for these printers is to use self-aligning bronze bushings for the X-carriage. I was frustrated that there were not a lot of options available that made use of those bushings. This thing is an attempt to provide more options. The OpenSCAD file has many selectable choices.
  • Use four bushings, or three with just the right bushing on the second rail, or three with just the left bushing on the second rail
  • Include fan mounts on any combination of left, right, and rear
  • Use traditional 40mm fan mounts, or hinged fan mounts
  • For rear fan mount, optionally use a 60mm size
  • Use slides rather than bushings on the second rail
  • Include tensioning for the X-belt on either left or right
  • If tensioning is included allow for a half-twist in the belt
    • In addition, many of the dimensions (like the thickness of the carriage) can be modified. To use this, open the .scad file in OpenSCAD. Near the top of the file are a series of parameters. Set those parameters to reflect the X-carriage you want to create. Render the X-carriage with F6. Export the design as an STL file, and then slice and print as usual. This is still a Work in Progress because I have not tested all of the possible options. The main parts I have been working with are three bushing configurations with hinged fan mounts and a half-twist belt tensioner. That is the configuration included in the included STL file. In particular, I am still doing some testing on the standard fan mount and the slider. I think those are working properly, but they might still need some tweaking. The belt tensioner uses one M4x30mm screw and one M4 nut. The X-belt does a half twist before going around the idler, so that the smooth back rather than the teeth rides across the idler. The belt then passes underneath the clamp area of the X-carriage, around the tensioning ram, and then clamps onto the top of the X-carriage. Turn the M4 screw to increase or decrease the tension. The hinge mounts use two M3x25mm screws, four M3 washers, and two M3 nuts. I had to use a wrench to hold the M3 nut while tightening the screw to get it tight enough to hold the fan angle. It might be worth tightening on a second nut to lock the first or to put a dab of paint on the threads. I am not yet sure how prone the fan hinge will be to vibrating loose without one of these techniques. The belt is clamped to the X-carriage the same as with other X-carriages. The clamps, however, are not included as part of this thing. If you find anything that is not working properly, or have suggestions for improvements, please let me know in the comments. Update 2012-09-07: I am now running this X-carriage on my printer and it works well. I made a number of changes since the original post. I have made the hotend hole just a little bigger. I always had to open that up with knives and files to fit my Budaschnozzle. That should be less necessary now. I made the sliders better hold the 1/8 inch rod intended to fit into the holes. I included a tensioner for those who do not want to half-twist the belt. I added a fan mount in the rear, and allowed for a 60mm fan in that position. I still have this marked a work in progress since I have not built and used all of the possible options. I do not, however, expect it will change much more unless someone reports a problem with one of the configurations.

comments.text: Hi I tried to open this up in openscad, had to figure out to install Greg's Configruation.scad file...but the nut traps just aren't showing up...is there another step I'm missing?  Thanks!
comments.author: seravi

comments.text: Hi Seravi,  My best guess is that you do not have functions.scad.  My object uses the polyhole and nut functions from that file.  To make things a bit easier, I have uploaded the copy of configuration.scad, functions.scad, and metric.scad that I used for this file.  If that doesn't solve it, let me know and I will try to look into it a little more.
comments.author: seravi

comments.text: It works!  I had to add include commands for the two new libraries, but then it worked like a charm.  I'm going to print once I swap from PLA to ABS.  Thanks again!
comments.author: orgemd

comments.text: Super, I'll try it out, thanks!
comments.author: orgemd

comments.text: Hi do you have the source or part # for the busings? thanks
comments.author: jtktam

comments.text: I have always bought mine from http://www.techpaladin.comwww.techpaladin.com where they are sold as 8mm or 10mm bronze sleeves.Â  I have seen the same parts available from other sources.Â  They are often sold as self-aligning bushings, or sintered bronze bushings.Â  I believe the most common manufacturer (although there are probably several) would be SDP/SI.Â  From them, I believe the 8mm part is A 7Z41MPSB08M, and the 10mm part is A 7Z41MPSB10M.Â  They are sold as sintered bronze, press-fit, sleeve bearings from SDP/SI.Â  Please keep in mind that I have not ordered those parts directly from SDP/SI - I am identifying that as the correct part strictly from the description and dimensions.
comments.author: jtktam

comments.text: Just wanted to say that this carriage is awesome. A thousand times better than the screw-on bearing holders. Those 8 screws give you a lot of grief since you have toÂ carefullyÂ adjust the tension on each one to have a smooth axis.
comments.author: jothan

comments.text: Thanks for the compliment.Â  I don't like the screw on versions either.Â  Although it provides some ability to compensate for minor build issues, it can be a great challenge to get them lined up in a way that does not cause binding.Â  The part that this is derived from (by techpaladin) did not use the screw on holders, and I thought that it was a lot better.Â  The only problem I had with that one is that I wanted more options with it.Â  I find especially that three rather than four bushings makes a big difference.Â  I also wanted fan mounts and wanted to make the carriage a little beefier.
comments.author: jothan

Based on the model by Revennant (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:158240), I modified this to take an iPhone 4/4S so that my phone can rule the seven kingdoms..
ahem UPDATE: I have successfully printed the Throne with the 4S dock piece. This took 23 hours 7 minutes but was completely worth it. It used just over a half a spool of ABS. I have removed the old version and left only the files which are actually dimensionally correct (and based off the high res model). I have also uploaded images of the final print and some videos. One is a time lapse of the print and the other is a demo of the sound function. UPDATE: I have taken the new High Resolution model also posted by Revennant and modified this file for this model. I fixed the issues with the other model being utterly huge and the dimensions being overwhelming for a makerbot and made it fit into the bed of a Replicator 2X (should also fit the Replicator 2 which is a slightly larger volume).
The model to see is the Throne With Sound Holes.stl
I included the Geomagic Design X / Rapidform file for those who wanted to attempt to edit this.
Took like an hour to slice and the way I'm going to attempt to print it is on it's back with color matched raft and color matched supports. Build says it will take 23 hours on 0.3 mm layer height and 10% infill (Default "Low" setting). Will use approximately half a full spool (~500 g of plastic material). Totally absolutely worth it. (i hope).
There is an insert so that pieces can be designed for other phones. I have made it for the iphone 4S with no case right now but more designs will follow (4S with otterbox, 5S, 5S with lifeproof case, are some of the first to follow).
The model "Cavity Bodies" is the body which i used to cut the cavity for the throne inside. I based the basic geometry for the internal sound cavity off the iphone dock by Parmsco (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193177/). There are sound holes in the front to let the music out and to utter commands over the speakerphone to your subjects.
Anyway, I haven't printed one yet but I am going to try one tomorrow night (Friday 11/7/14) and see how it goes.

Took like an hour to slice and the way I'm going to attempt to print it is on it's back with color matched raft and color matched supports. Build says it will take 23 hours on 0.3 mm layer height and 10% infill (Default "Low" setting). Will use approximately half a full spool (~500 g of plastic material). Totally absolutely worth it. (i hope).
There is an insert so that pieces can be designed for other phones. I have made it for the iphone 4S with no case right now but more designs will follow (4S with otterbox, 5S, 5S with lifeproof case, are some of the first to follow).

remixed_from.author: DesignMakeTeach
remixed_from.title: 5mm Aegis Clip for Athena Makeover Kit

description.text: This is a civilian version of the Faire Play Recurve Bow and Bracer released by Zheng3 to mark his Faire Play Kickstarter reaching the initial fundraising goal. The original bracer is oversize to fit around plate armor. I have remixed the bracer to fit a standard Barbie-style doll arm while maintaining compatibility with the original Recurve Bow. When I attempted to print the original Recurve Bow, even after making some adjustments, my printer hit the hard end stops. I realized the Zheng Industries forges were producing full scale war bows intended to punch through enemy armor. The civilian version of the bow is scaled down 75% in length and width to fit a smaller build plate (110mmx110mm) but maintains the full thickness of the original for strength. The loop for the arrows and the indentation for the bracer have been kept at their original size. Meaning the civilian bow is compatible with the original bracer. Bow has also been altered for a right hand draw. The set is perfect for a variety of bow wielding characters such as Merida, Katniss/Gale or the kids from Red Dawn (original). I sponsored the Faire Play: Barbie-Compatible 3D Printed Medieval Armor at https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/191197566/faire-play-barbie-compatible-3d-printed-medieval-a and you should too.
Printed in PLA 0.2 mm layer height. Experimenting with Loctite Plastics Bonding System which claims to fuse hard-to-bond plastic. Seems to have done a good job with attaching the bracer to the bow.

This is a simple, bare-bones mount for an umbrella with a 5/16" shaft.  It includes an adjustable mount for a 2 1/4" light fixture and mounts to a standard 1 5/8" tripod base.  Because it is designed to mount on a tripod it does not have any angle adjustments as these can be done with the tripod itself.  Perfect if you're on a budget and will be doing handheld shots without your proper tripod.  The base is slightly offset from the superstructure to allow it to print flat without a raft.  This may cause some issues when printing the rear bevel on the base but hasn't affected the functionality with either of the prints I've done.  The lamp and umbrella interfaces can be tightened by adding 1/4" and 3/16" bolts.

I wanted more consistent Z height so I made this to hold a small switch.
Nothing fancy but it works.
Groove on the back to key in to the vertical rod.
Two holes to fit some raw 1.75mm filament in to help hold the switch it in place. (not really necessary)
2 zip ties and a dab of hot glue. Glue just prevents it from sliding up the rod.
This was installed on a One-up but I don't see why it would not work on a Two-UP. Switch used:
http://www.digikey.com/product-search/en?x=0&y=0&lang=en&site=us&KeyWords=sw503-nd
This is a common switch, used a lot in computer mice. Got a old mouse laying around? :) G code to use only one endstop:
G28 Z ; Home Z only

See photo for wiring.
Ground pin is Z-stop Pin 3, the closer of the 3 pins to the USB port.
Signal Pin is Z-stop Pin 1, the farther one from the USB port.
Center Pin is not used. Add "G28 Z ; Home Z only" to your start G code and you should be set.

comments.text: since you are only using 2 lines pins do not matter. just leave the center free. i used a mouse button and i had to wire NO instead of nc to trigger. also m119 command will tell if it triggers or not. I had to go searching for this. thx for the design i am printing it now
comments.author: pen25

title: Mutable Instruments Shruthi-1 Synthesizer Printable Case

description.text:
Hello everybody
I have purchased this great little synth from France, already built, because my soldering skills leave a lot to be desired, nevertheless I planned of building the case myself so here it is. It was designed for and printed with an UP plus printer, but I guess any printer that can manage a form of support structure would work just fine. The printed model was printed in ABS with a 0.2 mm layer resolution and took around 14 hours of printing. Thanks for your time and happy printing and playing with this wonderful synth. This is a homemade design and was tested solely on my synth therefore I am not responsible if something goes wrong while building it.

Appart from the case the only additional thing you'd need are 10 nuts and bolts and a few drops of superglue for the facing of the LCD.I don't know the diameter of the screws but it's the same as those used on the synth. Actually the screws on the bottom of the synth proved to be too short and I used them on the upper side of the main cover, where the screws should be as short as possible so they won't damage the upper board of the synth. The building/assembling steps I took were as follows:
  • Print the parts
  • Unscrew the screws holding the bottom card of the synth
  • Attach the synth to the bottom part using 4 screws
  • Glue the LCD facing to the top part
  • Put all the nuts in their sockets
  • Attach the top side, then the back side, the left and right side.
  • Each side part has two sockets where, eventually, you can glue some rubber feet to the sides (like I did) to keep the synth from sliding around on your desk

title: TableTop Day 2014 Mini Trophy of Still-Pretty-Cool-But-Not-As-Awesome

description.text: In honor and support of International TableTop day (http://www.tabletopday.com/) I am releasing this mini version of the TableTop Trophy of Awesome (http://wilwheaton.net/2014/02/even-more-fun-with-3d-printing/) designed by me. This was designed to be much smaller, hence many of the details of the larger version have been culled. This would make a great door gift or prize for people at your international tabletop event. (I hate to release this before I've had a chance to print it, but I'm up to my ears in paid jobs, I am 100% sure it will print successfully and I want people to have time to print their own for the event, so I am releasing it now. Enjoy.) Thanks to Kabong for printing it and letting me use the picture. Play more games. If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays

comments.text: ring band looks thick but it's not noticeable after printing I found the ring of tinkercad too thin to print properly without adding extra layers the inner diameter is not affected by the extra layers in it they were added on the outside of the measured ring. I have a plastic rendering of another ring I made before coming to thingiverse based on the same band and it looks just like and average ring band.

title: Y Limit Switch Brackets for Taig Mill

description.text:
(initially posted as "endstops" -- which as was pointed out on the Taig yahoo group is probably poor naming) Limit switch holders for Taig mill. Very much work in progress. Absolutely no guarantees -- though would love feedback if you try them. These are designed with covered sides to help prevent swarf from getting into the switch. Hardware Needed per limit switch:
Switch (I used Cherry E-61 switches)
2 - 10-24 x 7/16 screws (or 10-24 x 1/2 and 1 or 2 10-24 washers)
2 - 10-24 nuts
2 - 2-56 x 7/16 screws
2 - 2-56 nuts

I printed mine solid @ 0.2mm height to minimize flex. Mount below table on the right, using the slot on the ways for alignment. One of the mounting holes for each switch is made into an arc so the amount the switch arm protrudes can be adjusted by rotating before screwing in place. Note the switch should be mounted inside the "box" -- it's meant to protect the switch from chips. I've uploaded the OpenSCAD code in case anyone wants to play with it. It's pretty ugly -- sorry about that.

author: tymm

I took those two excellent designs to add the continents texture to the cup.
Cup: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:120282
Globe: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17336
The model was cleaned up using netfabb Basic.
I have printed a 36,5cm high version and painted it with gold color. Looks decent and will give our World Cup evenings a special deco touch.And I used it to create the photo named "July 13, 2014 (pre-inacted)". :-)
Edit June 10, 2014: As observed by Alan (Alzibiff) the photos show additional text at the bottom of the trophy. These characters are the result of further customizing the model, they are not part of the STL provided here.

comments.text: I COLLECTED IT YEA
comments.author: Royroy321

comments.text: My cup stopped printing before the globe. Is this design in two parts?
comments.author: roneill16

comments.text: Bobby, no, this version comes in one piece. Maybe you have used the file MissC3D published yesterday, it is a scaled version and comes in two pieces. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:373658http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... to check. Cheers, Mario
comments.author: roneill16

comments.text:
The photographs don't seem to match the STL - the writing at the bottom of the trophy in the photographs is not part of the downloadable file. Is there a reason for this? Nice looking model though!
Alan
comments.author: Alzibiff

comments.text: Alan, very well observed. The writing is just part of an additional personalization step, I wanted my name to be printed on the bottom of the cup. I figured, other people would not be interested in having that version, so I published the STL of the cup without the letters. I apologize for not mentioning that in the description. Thanks for commenting! Cheers, Mario
comments.author: Alzibiff

comments.text:
No worries Mario, I was not sure whether or not the FIFA trophy had letters on the base anyway! Currently printing (and have been for the last 5h 30m) a version scaled to fit my M90. 0.8 size makes it around 194mm. I am using Faberdashery Bling Bling gold but not sure whether I have enough left to complete the print! (So I might end up spraying it if I have to push in some other colour to finish it off). Will post a "made it" once finished. Thanks again for the model.
Alan
